org.obd.query
Interface Shard

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractShard, AbstractSQLShard, ChadoSQLShard, InMemoryShard, MultiShard, MutableOBOSessionShard, OBDSimpleSQLShard, OBDSQLShard, OBOSessionShard, RDFShard, WrappedOBDRestShard
public interface Shard

Interface for accessing a repository/repositories of ontology-based annotations

Significant implementations:

  • OBDSQLShard
    • -- database access
  • OBOSessionShard
    • -- in-memory access (persistence via obof or owl files)
  • MultiShard
    • -- mediator access to >1 shard
  • RDFShard
    • -- wraps an OBD triplestore (IN PROGRESS)
The methods here present essentially two methods of access:
  • advanced query based access, via construction of QueryTerm objects
  • simple canned template based access
The latter method presents convenience methods such as org.obd.query.Shard#getAnnotationStatementsForNode() which are themselves typically implemented behind the scenes as wrapper calls using the appropriate query object

Author:
cjm

getStatements

java.util.Collection<Statement> getStatements(java.lang.String sourceId)
fetches all statements from a particular source. All statements, whether LinkStatements or LiteralStatements, should have some source. This may be identical to the source of the node, or it may be separate (for example, it is valid for a non_OMIM source to annotate an OMIM ID).

Caution: may return multiple results

Parameters:
sourceId - a unique global identifier for the source. E.g. OMIM
Returns:
all statements that have this source

getStatementsByQuery

java.util.Collection<Statement> getStatementsByQuery(QueryTerm queryTerm)
given a query, find matching statements from shard

Example: LinkQueryTerm partOfNucleusQuery = new LinkQueryTerm(partOf, new LabelQueryTerm(AliasType.ANY_LABEL, "nucleus")); stmts = shard.getStatementsByQuery(new AnnotationLinkQueryTerm(partOfNucleusQuery));

Parameters:
queryTerm -
Returns:
non-null Collection of any kind of Statement
See Also:
QueryTest

Here "about" corresponds to "subject" in RDF terminology. Each Statement has a subject -- what the statement is about.

id - the unique global identifier for the node that the statement is about

getSimilarNodes

java.util.List<ScoredNode> getSimilarNodes(java.lang.String nodeId)
given an annotated entity node (e.g. a PMID or a genotype ID) this will return all similar nodes attached to a score for that node. The similarity is determined by finding other annotated entities with similar annotation profiles. The score is an uncorrected p-value (low values close to zero indicate high degree of similarity).

Parameters:
nodeId -
Returns:
all comparable nodes with similarity p-value

compareAnnotationsBySourcePair

SimilarityPair compareAnnotationsBySourcePair(java.lang.String aeid,
                                              java.lang.String src1,
                                              java.lang.String src2,
                                              LinkQueryTerm closureQueryTerm)
Given an annotated entity (such as a human gene or genotype), and two annotation sources (eg fb and zfin), return a SimilarityPair object that summarises the total set of attributes of that AE as determined by the two sources; here the set of attributes is the classes used to annotate the AEs, plus their "parents" as determined by the closureQueryTerm This method is most useful when there are two or more agents annotating the same entity; for example, as in double-blind experiments or the NCBO IMIM 3x coverage annotation of OMIM genotypes. Ideally different curators will annotate the same genotype in different ways (the similiarity score in the SimilarityPair object will be high), but in practice this will not be the case.

Parameters:
aeid - - e.g. OMIM:601653
src1 - - e.g. omim_phenotype_zfin
src2 -
closureQueryTerm -
Returns:

compareAnnotationsBySourcePair

SimilarityPair compareAnnotationsBySourcePair(java.lang.String aeid,
                                              java.lang.String src1,
                                              java.lang.String src2)
As before, but with the default closureQueryTerm, i.e. the closure over any relation

Parameters:
aeid -
src1 -
src2 -
Returns:

compareAnnotationsByAnnotatedEntityPair

SimilarityPair compareAnnotationsByAnnotatedEntityPair(java.lang.String aeid1,
                                                       java.lang.String aeid2,
                                                       LinkQueryTerm closureQueryTerm,
                                                       LinkQueryTerm annotationQueryTerm)
Given two annotated entities (e.g. two genes, perhaps connected by homology), find the attributes they share (and the attributes that differ between them) based on annotation and deductive closure as determined bu closureQueryTerm

Parameters:
aeid1 -
aeid2 -
Returns:

compareAnnotationsByAnnotatedEntityPair

SimilarityPair compareAnnotationsByAnnotatedEntityPair(java.lang.String aeid1,
                                                       java.lang.String aeid2)
Given two annotated entities (e.g. two genes, perhaps connected by homology), find the attributes they share (and the attributes that differ between them) based on annotation and deductive closure. Here the default closureQueryTerm is used (i.e. closure over any relation)

Parameters:
aeid1 -
aeid2 -
Returns:

getAnnotatedNodeCount

int getAnnotatedNodeCount()
fetches total number of annotated entities in shard. An annotated entity is any entity that is represented by a node that is the target of an annotation statement

Returns:
total number of annotated entities

includesEntailedStatements

java.lang.Boolean includesEntailedStatements()
Most shards provide access to the deductive closure of all statements. Future versions will allow more detailed introspection to determine completeness w.r.t different language sub-fragments

Returns:
whether the shard includes *any* entailed statements

mapNodeToSubset

                                                java.lang.String subsetId)

getAnnotatedEntityCountBySubset

java.util.Map<Node,java.lang.Integer> getAnnotatedEntityCountBySubset(AnnotationLinkQueryTerm aqt,
                                                                      java.lang.String subsetId)
                                                                      throws ShardExecutionException
Given a set of annotations and a subset/view over an ontology(s), map all annotations to the subset and then count the number of DISTINCT annotated entities related to the mapped class. The deductive closure is used here.

Formally: count(n) = |e| where e R n Here, e R n denotes that there is some relation R between e and n that can be deduced from some annotation, plus the axioms in the ontology. The value of R is by default left unbound; it can be set by passing in the appropriate annotation query object For example, if the annotations contained: genotype1 size of Eyeball genotype2 thickness of Wall of eyeball genotype2 color of Iris Then the count for "Eyeball" would be 2, because both genotypes are related to "Eyeball" via some chain of relations (specific relations can be selected using methods on the annotation query. In the example above, part_of is included) Note that if the subset contains the class "Organ", then these annotated entities would also count for this class

Parameters:
aqt - query for fetching annotations. If null will select all
subsetId - identifier for the subset/view to map to
Returns:
counts broken down by class node used to annotate
Throws:
ShardExecutionException

simpleClosureOver

void simpleClosureOver(Graph graph,
                       java.lang.String seedId,
                       java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> relIds,
                       java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> reverseRelIds)

Parameters:
graph - - all links are added to this graph
seedId - - initial starting node
relIds - - relations to traverse, in a subject->target direction
reverseRelIds - - relations to traverse, in a target->subject direction
